title: Opistophthalmus pugnax
text:
The pugnacious burrowing scorpion ("Opistophthalmus pugnax") is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>n <a href="scorpion">scorpion</a>.
Description.
These muddy-looking scorpions are characterized by <a href="wikt%3Acorrugation">corrugation</a>s on the last <a href="sternite">sternite</a>, stiff hairs (<a href="setae">setae</a>), and highly recurved <a href="tarsus%20%28skeleton%29">tarsal</a> claws. Males have corrugations on the last two sternites. They grow up to 70 mm in length.
Distribution and habitat.
A fan-shaped <a href="burrow">burrow</a> with an enlarged part for resting or consuming prey is constructed under rocks and other surface debris. It is a very common species on rocky outcrops and ridges in the north-central <a href="Free%20State%20%28province%29">Free State</a> and <a href="Gauteng">Gauteng</a> provinces of South Africa.
Behaviour.
Despite its species name, it is not particularly aggressive and very rarely enters houses. The female gives birth to <a href="litter">litter</a>s of up to 25.
